Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 47936  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
November  2013 
 
 
 
Capacity Development for the Supply Chain Finance 
Program  
(Cofinanced by the Financial Sector Development Partnership 
Fund and the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  PFI  –  partner financial institution 
  SCF  –  supply chain financing 
  SMEs  –   small and medium-sized enterprises 
  
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting  –  General intervention 
classification 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Industry and trade (trade and services) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), regional cooperation and integration (trade 
and  investments),  capacity  development  (institutional 
development) 
Location impact  –  Rural (medium), urban (medium), national (medium), regional 
(high) 
Partnerships  –  Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund; Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Fund 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  T. Freeland, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  C. Engstrom, Private Sector Financial Institutions Division, PSOD 
   
Team leader  S. Beck, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Team members  E. Mangampat, Investment Officer, PSOD 
   
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CONTENTS 
Page 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
A.  Impact and Outcome  2 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  2 
C.  Cost and Financing  3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  3 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  4 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  5     
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  7 
3.  Outline Terms of Reference for Consultants  8 
         
SUPPLEMENTARY APPENDIX (available on request) 
Links to Country and Regional Strategies and Business Plans

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will support implementation of the first Supply Chain 
Finance Program of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which the ADB Board of Directors 
approved on 8 November 2012. The TA will be used primarily to engage consultants to conduct 
due diligence and monitoring of risks, and to help administer the program. The program will 
provide  guarantees  to  and  debt  financing  (both  without  a  government  guarantee)  through 
partner financial institutions (PFIs) to support payments throughout the supply chain; and will 
enable companies in developing member countries (DMCs) to improve their cash flow, thereby 
enabling growth and job creation.1  
 
2.  The Board approved a program limit of up to $200,000,000 at any time. Such financing 
support will be on a rolling basis. Guarantees and loans will be provided to and through PFIs to 
cover the risk of nonpayment under supply chain transactions. These loans and guarantees will 
be matched in equal or greater amounts by the PFI to the same obligors. ADB will assume 
corporate  risk,  including  that  related  to  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs),  in 
conjunction with PFIs.  ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department, which is implementing the 
program, will conduct its own due diligence and internal approval process on these underlying 
risks involving ADB’s Office of Risk Management. 
 
3.  The program is regional and aims to encompass as many DMCs as possible, including 
those benefiting from Asian Development Fund resources. While ADB will make every effort to 
diversify its geographic exposure and support, the program will nonetheless be linked to where 
PFIs have supply chain financing (SCF) exposure. The design and monitoring framework can 
be found in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Unlike the advanced “just-in-time” efficiencies obtained in the physical supply chain 
since  the  1990s,  the  financial  supply  chain  is  still  primarily  a  manual,  nonintegrated,  and 
inefficient process. Under the current system, cash flow for working capital is trapped in the 
supply chain, undermining the ability of DMC companies, especially SMEs, to expand and 
create more jobs. For example, having to wait for payment as long as 6 months after shipment 
may mean having to shut down operations, which runs the risk of losing new contracts and 
delaying the processing of existing orders in the meantime. Receiving cash flow even just 30 
days earlier could make a substantial difference—DMC companies would have a steady flow of 
working capital to maintain production capacity, retain staff, and ultimately expand operations 
and employ more people. 
 
5.  While ADB has developed a strong capacity to support trade, including among SMEs 
through its Trade Finance Program, there are gaps in ADB’s offerings and capacity to support 
SMEs in real sector supply chains, which the Supply Chain Finance Program can fill. Unlike the 
Trade Finance Program, the Supply Chain Finance Program will assume corporate risk, not 
bank risk, and will support domestic as well as cross-border supply chains. 
 
6.  SCF has the potential to minimize the two greatest impediments to DMC companies 
accessing finance: low credit rating and lack of collateral. Unlike traditional risk assessments 
                                                
1 The first three PFIs are anticipated to be Standard Chartered Bank, BNP Paribas, and Citibank. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 October 2013.

2   
that focus almost exclusively on financials and collateral, SCF focuses its assessment on the 
strength and longevity of a supply chain, and the mutual dependence between buyer and 
supplier. In assessing risk and working with PFIs to finance supply chains, the TA will inspire 
this shift in thinking, which should result in more systemic support for DMC companies long after 
ADB’s obligations and liabilities under the program are discharged by 31 August 2018. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  The TA will be used primarily to support the implementation of the SCF by engaging 
consultants to conduct due diligence and performance monitoring of companies. In addition, 
consultants engaged under the TA will help administer the program.  
 
8.  An important element of the TA, and a feature that also distinguishes the Supply Chain 
Finance Program from the Trade Finance Program, concerns its proposed focus on assessing 
and monitoring SME and corporate risk. ADB currently lacks experience in assessing and 
monitoring this risk, which impedes its ability to implement projects directly impacting DMC 
companies. The TA, which will be critical to the implementation of the program, will focus on 
obligor risk assessments, and monitoring and administration of SCF transactions. While the 
primary beneficiary of the TA will be DMC companies through the resulting program financing, 
an ancillary beneficiary will be ADB itself. ADB’s own technical capacity in working with DMC 
companies will be enhanced and this will position ADB to consider and implement new SME-
supporting projects in the future. 
 
9.  SCF is linked to the ADB Financial Sector Operational Plan,3 to various strategies and 
business  opportunities  presented  in  country  partnership  strategies,  regional  cooperation 
strategies  (i.e.,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  and  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic 
Cooperation),  and  country  operations  business  plans.  A  review  of  these  documents 
underscores the importance of trade finance capacity development in DMCs to enable ADB to 
meet its development objectives. An overview of some of the specific country and regional 
strategies  and  business  plans  with  direct  links  to  the  TA  is  provided  in  a  supplementary 
appendix. 
   
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be broader access to SCF for companies in DMCs.  Access to SCF for 
DMC companies is expected to increase by 25% by 2020.  The outcome will be partner financial 
institutions broadening their SCF portfolio.  By providing resources required to implement the 
program, it is anticipated that at least $500 million (ADB’s portion of risk: $200 million on a 
revolving basis) will be provided as SCF to DMC companies between 2013 and 2018.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will enable ADB to engage consultants to assist ADB in the implementation of 
the program. Consultants will be hired to conduct the following key activities critical to the 
implementation of the program: 
(i)  conduct in-depth due diligence and risk analysis on DMC companies in which ADB 
would assume risk under the program; 
                                                
3  ADB. 2011. Financial Sector Operational Plan. Manila.

3 
(ii)  administer transactions and perform monitoring assessments on DMC companies 
and PFIs; 
(iii)  prepare  two  reports  per  annum  (2–3  pages  in  length)  detailing  program 
implementation progress and challenges; 
(iv)  prepare an interim and an annual report detailing the development impact of the 
program, including against DMF indicators; 
(v)  motivate SMEs to participate in the program; and 
(vi)  conduct seminars and trainings on SCF in two countries. 
 
12.  The TA will have three outputs: 
(i)  Establish  the  program,  with  approximately  four  PFIs  enrolled  by  2015.  The 
program will mobilize private sector funds for SCF in DMCs by sharing risk and 
working  in  cooperation  with  PFIs.  As  the  TA  is  critical  to  implementing  the 
program, it will play a pivotal role in developing partnerships that will result in 
more support to DMC companies and therefore economic growth, job creation, 
and ultimately poverty alleviation. 
(ii)  Improve knowledge of SCF among key government officials, financial institutions, 
and entrepreneurs who will be trained on the functions and benefits of SCF in 
two seminars to be conducted by 2015. SCF is at an early stage of development 
in DMCs. Even for countries with more developed finance sectors, the availability 
of SCF is limited. The seminars will contribute to the development of SCF in 
countries where it is still at a nascent stage of development. 
(iii)  Increase the number of DMC companies with access to SCF from PFIs by 3% by 
2015.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which (i) $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund4 and administered by ADB; and 
(ii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Fund.5  
 
14. The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem for international consultants, national 
consultants, conference-related expenditures, and miscellaneous expenses. A detailed cost 
breakdown and proposed financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will require about 96 person-months of individual consulting inputs from two 
international and two national consultants. Recruitment of consultants will be in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Consultants 
engaged under the TA will work in ADB headquarters, and extensive travel is expected. In 
addition  to  conducting  due  diligence,  drafting  credit  applications,  monitoring  risk,  and 
administering the program, consultants and resource persons may be engaged by ADB to 
conduct seminars or training. Terms of reference for the consultants are provided in Appendix 3. 
Equipment (smartphones and data and communication plans) will be procured in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time) and will be retained 
                                                
4  Contributor: the Government of Luxembourg. 
5  Established by ADB.

4   
by ADB following TA completion. Implementation is anticipated by end January 2014 with the 
signing of a supply chain finance agreement with a partner financial institution. Disbursements 
under the agreement are anticipated by end first quarter 2014.  Due diligence and risk analysis 
on companies, and administration and monitoring of the program will be performed on an on-
going basis from Q1 2014 to October 2015. 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency while the Private Sector Operations Department will 
administer and implement the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  The grant of $800,000 will be used to start implementation of the program.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund; and (ii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis, both for 
Capacity Development for the Supply Chain Finance Program, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

she acts as a resource person. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

8   Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objective and Purpose of the Assignment  
 
1.  Under  the  technical  assistance  (TA),  consultants  will  be  hired  to  assist  in  the 
implementation of the Supply Chain Finance Program f the Asian Development Bank (ADB) by 
providing the outputs referred to in the design and monitoring framework. Additional consultants 
may be engaged for some TA components, as and when required. 
 
2.  The TA will implement the program and therefore increase the capacity of companies, 
especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), to grow and employ more people. In 
addition,  the  TA’s  role  in  implementing  the  program  will  result  in  SMEs  traditionally  not 
considered “bankable” gaining access to finance. This is to be achieved primarily through 
financial analysis and due diligence of potential partner financial institutions (PFIs), obligors, and 
related risks, all of which are required for the program to be implemented. The TA may also be 
used to provide training and knowledge dissemination seminars, especially as it may concern 
expanding the program to Asian Development Fund countries. 
 
3.  The consultants will (i) liaise with (potential) PFIs; (ii) conduct due diligence on potential 
PFIs; (iii) conduct financial and other risk-related assessments on potential obligors and related 
parties; (iv) based on the results of the abovementioned due diligence, financial analysis, and 
other risk-related assessments, draft credit applications for ADB consideration; (v) conduct 
annual reviews of PFIs, obligors, and related risks; (vi) draft annual review appraisals for ADB 
consideration; (vii) monitor portfolios in accordance with ADB documentation establishing and 
approving the program, and recommend improvements or additional TA; and (viii) conduct and 
draft development impact analyses and case studies as required. 
 
B.  Required Inputs 
 
1.  Consultants  
 
4.  The four consultants (two international and two national, 96 person-months)  will be 
based in Manila at ADB headquarters; travel will be required. They will coordinate with various 
financial  institutions,  obligors,  ADB  regional  departments,  the  program  team  (within  ADB’s 
Private Sector Operations Department), and ADB’s Office of Risk Management. 
 
5.  To implement the program, the consultants’ work will focus on (i) financial analysis; 
(ii) due  diligence;  and  (iii)  writing  of  credit  applications,  annual  reviews,  and  reports.  
Qualifications for consultants include the following: 
(i)  suitability to undertake the responsibilities mentioned above at the required level; 
(ii)  excellent oral and written communication skills in English; 
(iii)  excellent presentation skills; 
(iv)  strong knowledge of financial institutions, SME risk assessments, and country 
risk analysis; 
(v)  experience working in and with financial institutions and SMEs; 
(vi)  significant international experience working in emerging markets; 
(vii)  experience in financial analysis and due diligence on SMEs; and 
(viii)  willingness to travel extensively. 
 
6.  The tasks of the consultants will include the following: 
(i)  acquire financial information on obligors and related risks;

Appendix 3  9 
(ii)  provide information to ADB's risk-rating model; 
(iii)  conduct financial and other analyses of financial information; 
(iv)  conduct due diligence on potential PFIs, obligors, and related risks, including but 
not  limited  to  (a)  assessing  corporate  governance,  anti-money-laundering 
policies, and management capabilities; (b) social and environmental safeguards; 
and (c) assessing the longevity, mutual dependence, and historical performance 
of parties to a supply chain; 
(v)  based on the information accumulated from (i) to (iv), draft credit applications for 
the program; 
(vi)  assess  program  implementation  and  performance  with  a  view  to  making 
recommendations for improvements; and 
(vii)  accumulate, analyze, and report on development results, metrics, or indicators 
related to the program, especially, but not exclusively, as they relate to the 
design and monitoring framework associated with the program.   
 
2.  Resource Persons  
 
7.  Resource  persons  (international  and  national)  may  be  engaged  to  assist  in  the 
preparation,  delivery,  and  conduct  of  in-country  consultations  as  well  as  knowledge 
dissemination and training seminars, and other targeted training events organized under this TA. 
In exceptional cases, ADB staff members with special knowledge and experience required for 
the conduct of specific TA assignments may be engaged as resource persons. 
 
C.  Outputs and Reporting Requirements 
 
8.  Outputs and reporting requirements for the consultants include the following: 
(i)  submit good-quality, cohesive due diligence reports, risk assessments, and credit 
applications for PFIs (4), obligors (40), and related risk parties; 
(ii)  submit annual reviews on all PFIs and obligors approved by ADB under 
paragraph 7(i) (30 obligor monitoring reports and four PFI monitoring reports); 
(iii)  conduct an industry sector survey to establish baselines for DMF purposes; 
(iv)  submit two reports per annum (2–3 pages in length) detailing implementation 
progress and challenges; and 
(v)  submit an interim and annual report detailing development impact of the 
program, including against design and monitoring framework indicators.
